title: 00 ‚Ä¢ Editor Basics
summary: Get familiar with the visual editor, create your first mesh, and explore the interface.

content.text: The Nostalgi2D editor is a web-based visual tool that helps you create game assets, design meshes, and manage your project without writing code. This tutorial will introduce you to the editor interface and basic workflows.
Starting the Editor
To launch the editor, navigate to your project directory and run the development server:

content.code:
cd Nostalgi2DTs/src
npm install
npm run dev --filter=editor

content.text: The editor will be available at http://localhost:5173
üí° The editor runs entirely in your browser and uses local storage to save your work.
Editor Interface Overview
The editor interface consists of several key panels:

items: Assets Panel (left): Browse and manage meshes, components, and other assets
Canvas Area (center): Visual workspace for designing meshes and scenes
Properties Panel (right): Edit properties of selected assets
Toolbar (top): Quick access to common tools and actions

content.alt: Editor interface showing the main panels and workspace
content.caption: The Nostalgi2D editor interface with labeled panels

content.text: Creating Your First Mesh
Meshes are the building blocks of your game's visual elements. Let's create a simple triangle mesh:

items: Open the Assets panel on the left side of the editor
Click the 'New Mesh' button at the top of the panel
Enter a name for your mesh (e.g., 'PlayerTriangle')
The mesh designer canvas will open in the center

content.alt: New Mesh button in the Assets panel
content.caption: Click 'New Mesh' to start creating a new mesh asset

content.text: Using the Mesh Designer
The mesh designer provides a canvas where you can add and arrange vertices to create custom shapes:

items: Click on the canvas to add vertices (points)
Right-click on a vertex to remove it
Vertices must be added in counter-clockwise order for proper rendering

content.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Meshes must be convex polygons. Concave shapes will not render correctly.
For a triangle, add three vertices in counter-clockwise order. The mesh designer will automatically connect them and show a preview with a fill color.

content.alt: Mesh designer canvas showing a triangle with three vertices
content.caption: Creating a triangle mesh by placing three vertices

content.text: Saving and Managing Meshes
Once you're happy with your mesh, save it to the asset library:

items: Click the 'Save' button in the mesh designer toolbar
Your mesh will appear in the Assets panel
You can edit it later by clicking on it in the Assets panel
Meshes are stored as JSON and can be exported for use in your game

content.text: Exploring Editor Plugins
The editor can be extended with plugins that add custom panels, tools, and functionality. Plugins are loaded automatically when the editor starts.
You can view available plugins and their panels in the View menu. Custom panels can be docked to any side of the editor workspace.
üí° Learn how to create your own editor plugins in the 'Editor Plugins' tutorial.
Next Steps
Now that you understand the editor basics, you're ready to dive deeper into mesh design and component creation. Continue to the next tutorial to master the mesh component designer workflow.
